reviewText:
Easy to pick up but hard to put down, oO is a great game for your collection if you enjoy minimalistic and difficult games such as Super Hexagon, Velocibox, The Collider, Pivvot etc. Like all of the forementioned games, it is fast paced, challenging and a fun way to kill a few minutes once in a while. Yes, it's difficult too, but it has a good learning curve and a nice variety of levels to progress through, thankfully it has a very helpful checkpoint mechanic as well.

Currently oO is incredibly cheap (¬£0.79 in my case) so I'd definitely recommend picking it up, there are certainly worse things you could be doing with 79p.

This game would certainly benefit from the addition of a level editor and Steam Achievements, hopefully something for the future.

reviewText: I wasn't expecting much out of this game for $1 but I was pleasantly surprised.  It's not the kind of game you think you'll be coming back to, but there is something addictive in it's simplicity and difficulty.\n\nThe concept is as simple as the graphics and the music in this game.  Your a circle, moving inside (or outside) of another another circle.  When you click the mouse, you switch which side of the circle you're in.  Use this simple little ability to move from circle to circle and make a path forward.  Then you start to throw in some spikes and obstacles and the game starts to feel a bit more rewarding.  Then you turn that up to 11 and you're screaming expletives at your computer screen and swearing on your mother's grave you will not be defeated by such a simple concept of a game.  It's fun, addicting, and rewarding.  The visuals are nothing impressive and I preferred to turn the sound off and play my own music, but for $1 it's worth your time.

reviewText:
I just bought this game to write a review as I've played this on my Android a lot so please don't go with my Steam Play hours.

Oo is one of my favorite game as it takes some patience for one to get pass a level. This game never gets boring because there's always some randomness which will keep you entertaining.

I've played this game on my Android and am glad they made one for the PC as well. The concept is pretty simple, you have a ball spinning around in the ring and you need to advance by switching from one ring to another where they get connected from.

It's not just that, each level gets more and more tough as these rings have spikes, they move in a wavy shape, screen angles rotate and some rings will drop in randomly.

Pros
Lots and lots of hours of fun
Difficulty at max
Unique pattern of gameplay on each level
Minimal Graphics
Dude, it's just 1$ game (I seriously seriously want that the developer of this game should sell it for 3$ atleast, I won't mind paying even 5$ for such a game honestly)
Cons (Actually none but some suggestions infact)
Level editor missing, will be fun to have one
Need an endless + random endless mode, not sure if it has one as I've not completed the game on my phone
Can improve graphics
Increase the damn price xD
Again, great piece of work, thanks for making this game.

reviewText:
It's a cheap one button game that's easy to wrap your head around, and isn't actually that difficult at all once you understand it. At least, I didn't have much trouble getting through it, but I don't cringe or get emotional when I die.

It's pretty clean, and for the price if you like your one button games, then you can safely enjoy a few hours with this.

I wish the music was catchier, it's too ambient for my tastes, and I feel like some  rhythm could be a nice addition. I liked the trippy levels for the visual effect, but don't see the allure of playing them per se.

It's a case of a game that delivers whats on the tin. You can tell what this game is about, and it is about that.

reviewText:
Starts out as a fairly challenging puzzle reflex game, but very quickly turns into nothing but frustration. Even though it does a few neat things in terms of level design, the lack of any other interesting mechanincs makes traveling  through these interesting levels really boring. Soundtrack is mediocre and visuals are simple yet pleasing. One thing i noted whilst playing the 2nd level was what SEEMED like input lag, where i hit spacebar and the related action would happen 0.5 seconds later. In a  game that requires split second reactions in order to proceed, this is a major drawback.

Summary:
Mechanics - Only one mechanic that's incorperated well into the level design.
Soundtrack - Nothing amazing, but it's not bad
Visuals - Simple stuff, nothing amazing
Final opinion - Wouldn't recomend this game unless you literally have nothing else to do

reviewText:

Either way it's a good pick up and play game and for the price you can't go wrong.
Watch the trailer for a few seconds and you'll know exactly what to expect. The checkpoints are well spaced to be difficult without being too frustrating.
If you want a simplistic, but well designed and responsive one-button game spend the dollar on this one.

reviewText:
So what is oO? That's a good question...
If you're after something easy and relaxing... this AINT it ;)
In oO you play as a little Circle, and you goal is to progress from circle to circle without much trouble initially.
But the further you get, the difficult ramps up and you'll end up needing to memorise certain areas to pass them. (After failing dozens of times at least)
If the original levels aren't enough, there's a variation of each, (I call it drunk mode)
Spikes, high speed movement, memorisation of patters and MORE spikes!
Let's not forget the survival level... Want to take it slow? NOPE! You've got a big scary red wall chasing you, and it only get faster for each checkpoint you hit.

Super fun game, and super cheap too! Highly Recommended for those with quick reflexes!

reviewText:
Tough-as-nails precision games like Super Meat Boy must do several things:

1. They must be difficult.
2. They must make the player feel like they can clear each stage/board/level, even if it takes 500 attempts.
3. They must strike a balance between the following reactions: (a) Oh, come on -- I totally]/i] landed one pixel to the left! (b) Oh, I timed that just a little wrong. (c) Oh my god. I can't believe I just did that. My incompetence is hilarious.

Oo strikes this balance perfectly. Reflexes, pattern recognition, and tiny bits of critical thinking all combine to make for a beautifully infuriating experience. The wavy boards are just silly, but I don't think they're required.

The music is decent, although I wish I could turn it down without turning it off. The sound design matches the minimalist visuals elegantly.

Well worth the low price.
voteText: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
HATE! LOVE! Don't like!
Why?

Hate:
It is a hard game that will punish you for any mistake that you make in which you are given all the details of how to die.

Love:
It is a simple idea and runs with it. It makes getting in and out of the game easy enough that if you only had 15 minutes to play a game, it would be fun (and difficult).

Don't like:
All the wavy levels give me motion sickness. It is hard to say that it is an extra bit of challenge when It feels more like a cop out answer.

All that aside. I still would recommend anyone that is looking for a hard game without the hard price tag.

P.S. It's stink'n hard and I will crush it!

While it's so easy to fail with such a minimalist game, the creator of oO hasn't put a foot wrong. The game is simple, the controls are (actually, the control is) snappy, the fast gameplay leaves hardly any margin for error, and that makes the completion of the levels all the more satisfying. Very enjoyable, very much recommended.

Also, my 2c on the Kongregate topic: if you played the game on Kongregate, and you enjoyed it, I'd recommend to buy it to support the developer. Especially since It's only 1 EUR.

Full Review:

~ Description ~

oO is a 2D game where you're a ball on the perimeter of a circle, and with a click you switch from either going around the inside of the circle or the outside. This is used to travel between circles and progress through the levels and to avoid spikes on your way.

~ Gamemodes ~

4 levels of increasing difficulty and new obstacles every level.
Endless mode, which gets harder as you go on, and every circle you progress through increases your score by one.
Bonus versions of each level, where everything has a wobbly effect, causing it to look like the ball is speeding up/slowing down, but it's still moving at the same consistent speed as in the normal levels.
~ Pros! ~

I picked up the game for only $0.89 when it was on sale
Good music that didn't get annoying throughout multiple hours of playtime.
Amazing level design and cycles that are easy to understand but hard to master
Very simple controls. Literally one button. (Space bar or Left Click)
When you die, you go back to the most recent checkpoint, and it restarts the cycle at a specific point, which makes the game far less frustrating than it may first seem.
~ Meh's... ~

I feel like the game scammed me a few times when switching from circle to circle, but that's probably just me trying to find an excuse to say it wasn't me.
When you use the menu button in the upper left corner while in a level, your ball switches sides of the circle before the menu pops up. It's a minor bug but it can screw you over sometimes.
No way to save your progress mid-level, but it doesn't really matter since the levels are somewhat short and can be done pretty quickly if you have practice and you know what you're doing.
~ Cons! ~

There are only four levels, plus the Endless mode, and no level creator/editor, making the game quite short.
The game may trigger motion sickness on the later levels if you're a bit sensitive to it.
~ Achievements ~

There are 6 achievements, one for beating each of the main levels, one for hitting a score of 15 in Endless, and one for hitting a score of 100 in Endless.

It may be due to my lack of experience in the game and/or just sucking at it in general, but hitting a score of 100 in Endless seems practically impossible to me at the moment.

~ Conclusion ~

If you really want the game, you can go ahead and pick it up for the full $3, but I would honestly wait for it to go on sale at least a little before getting it. I picked it up at the end of the Steam Winter Sale for just $0.89 and I'd consider that absolutely worth it.

The game itself is pretty entertaining and also got intense for the last two levels. Easy to pick up, difficult to master.

This game follows the same principle of Geometry Dash, but instead of squares and jumping, you control a small ball rolling along the lines of circles, avoiding stationary, moving and disappearing obstacles.

One major con is the number of levels. About 8 levels, plus a survival mode. And there's no leaderboard to compare your performance with other players'.

There really isn't much more to say of what this game's about, except it's definitly a rage game. You'll end up with a headache and with your blood pressure going through the roof - and possibly with a broken mouse/keyboard - but for what it costs, it's difficult not to recommend this game.

If you're bored and tired of complex games, give this one a try. Warning, though: you'll rage.

reviewText:
There is honestly nothing much to this game.
It's a solid game where the trailer basically explains everything, and pretty fun for a couple hours for only being a dollar.
So I don't have anything to say so I'll just cover what it offers and it's kongregate version.
There's 8 levels to this game, (4 regular, 4 distorted, 1 heat, 1 distorted heat.) In where you have to use second timing in order to advance through the circles. Left click where the two circles combine, and advance, all while avoiding spikes and red spikes. and blue moving spikes. You can also invert yourself outside of the circles in order to dodge spikes and other objects, but there's really only spikes.
The regular levels play the same just get harder with time, and while challenging, quite short.
The distorted levels are just the same levels as their counterparts just distorted to make the level a lot harder. It's actually quite difficult to progress when the circles are basically jelly.
The heat level is moving from circle to circle as fast as you can while running away from a red bar. That's why I call it 'heat'. You only get one life so it's basically a test to see how quickly and efficiently you can move without messing up or getting consumed. And the distorted level is once again the same thing, but the circles are jelly.
This is basically the game, I played the kongregate version a little bit, but google changed some stuff and now I can't run kongregate games without firefox. It's basically the same thing, but one level.
So this game is just a basic 'pick me up for a dollar' game. It's fun for a couple of hours, but the only replayability is getting 0 deaths in all levels, or trying to get a super high score in the heat levels.
Buy it if you want, but it's nothing exiciting.
You basically pay a dollar to get ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• off at how ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• your reflexes are. Pretty good deal if you ask me.

Full Review:

~ Description ~

oO is a 2D game where you're a ball on the perimeter of a circle, and with a click you switch from either going around the inside of the circle or the outside. This is used to travel between circles and progress through the levels and to avoid spikes on your way.

~ Gamemodes ~

4 levels of increasing difficulty and new obstacles every level.
Endless mode, which gets harder as you go on, and every circle you progress through increases your score by one.
Bonus versions of each level, where everything has a wobbly effect, causing it to look like the ball is speeding up/slowing down, but it's still moving at the same consistent speed as in the normal levels.
~ Pros! ~

I picked up the game for only $0.89 when it was on sale
Good music that didn't get annoying throughout multiple hours of playtime.
Amazing level design and cycles that are easy to understand but hard to master
Very simple controls. Literally one button. (Space bar or Left Click)
When you die, you go back to the most recent checkpoint, and it restarts the cycle at a specific point, which makes the game far less frustrating than it may first seem.
~ Meh's... ~

I feel like the game scammed me a few times when switching from circle to circle, but that's probably just me trying to find an excuse to say it wasn't me.
When you use the menu button in the upper left corner while in a level, your ball switches sides of the circle before the menu pops up. It's a minor bug but it can screw you over sometimes.
No way to save your progress mid-level, but it doesn't really matter since the levels are somewhat short and can be done pretty quickly if you have practice and you know what you're doing.
~ Cons! ~

There are only four levels, plus the Endless mode, and no level creator/editor, making the game quite short.
The game may trigger motion sickness on the later levels if you're a bit sensitive to it.
~ Achievements ~

There are 6 achievements, one for beating each of the main levels, one for hitting a score of 15 in Endless, and one for hitting a score of 100 in Endless.

It may be due to my lack of experience in the game and/or just sucking at it in general, but hitting a score of 100 in Endless seems practically impossible to me at the moment.

~ Conclusion ~

If you really want the game, you can go ahead and pick it up for the full $3, but I would honestly wait for it to go on sale at least a little before getting it. I picked it up at the end of the Steam Winter Sale for just $0.89 and I'd consider that absolutely worth it.

reviewText: It's the kind of game you play for 5 minutes before you start screaming, destory your keyboard and have the police called on you by your neighbours because they think you are murdering a 5 year old... ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• you neighbours.

Endless mode can brake quite alot or at least in my case it did. Some times the game would not register when i clicked or kill me if i clicked on the line, also sometimes there would be a spike glitched inside the line so it would be sticking out on both sides making it impossible to go around.
